statement:
**Theorem.** If the real function $f$ is periodic and over a interval,
the value of integral over a period interval is always the same, i.e.
$$\begin{aligned}
\int_a^{a+p}\!f(x)\,dx \;=\; \int_0^pf(x)\,dx \quad \forall\,a \in \mathbb{R}\end{aligned}$$
where $p$ is the period of $f$.\
[*Proof.*]{} The right hand side of the equation (1) is manipulated,
with one $x = t\!+\!p$: $$\begin{aligned}
\int_0^pf(x)\,dx & \;=\; \int_0^af(x)\,dx+\int_a^pf(x)\,dx\\
& \;=\; \int_0^af(x)\,dx+\int_a^{a+p}\!f(x)\,dx-\int_p^{a+p}\!f(x)\,dx\\ 
& \;=\; \int_0^af(x)\,dx+\int_a^{a+p}\!f(x)\,dx-\int_0^{a}f(t\!+\!p)\,dt\\
& \;=\; \int_0^af(x)\,dx+\int_a^{a+p}\!f(x)\,dx-\int_0^{a}f(t)\,dt\\
& \;=\; \int_a^{a+p}\!f(x)\,dx\end{aligned}$$

[8]{} : [*Johdatus korkeampaan analyysiin*]{}. Fourth edition. Werner
Söderström Osakeyhtiö, Porvoo ja Helsinki (1956). , .
